verses.text: The Lord spoke to Moses, saying,
verses.comment: This begins a new section where God gives Moses instructions regarding the daily, weekly, and festival offerings. The clarity of speech shows the authority of God in legislating proper worship.

verses.text: "Command the Israelites and say to them: You must be careful to present to Me My offerings, My food for My offerings by fire, a pleasing aroma to Me, at their appointed times."
verses.comment: God insists on the appointed times and designated offerings, underscoring the necessity of regulated, liturgical worship. The language of 'pleasing aroma' emphasizes the spiritual significance of obedience in worship (see also Eph. 5:2).

verses.text: And you shall say to them: This is the offering by fire which you shall offer to the Lord: two male lambs a year old without blemish, each day, as a continual burnt offering.
verses.comment: The lambs are to be without blemish, prefiguring the sinlessness of Christ (see 1 Pet. 1:19). The concept of daily sacrifice points to continual prayer and devotion.

verses.text: Offer one lamb in the morning and the other lamb at twilight,
verses.comment: Morning and evening offerings mirror the rhythm of daily prayer and worship—an early typology for the ancient practice of set times of prayer for believers.

verses.text: and a tenth of an ephah of fine flour as a grain offering, mixed with a quarter of a hin of beaten oil.
verses.comment: The grain offering, mingled with oil, represents the fruitful works of the faithful offered up to God. Oil is often symbolic of the Holy Spirit.

verses.text: This is the continual burnt offering, which was ordained at Mount Sinai as a pleasing aroma, an offering by fire to the Lord.
verses.comment: The continuity of the burnt offering reflects the perpetual nature of true worship, from Sinai onward. The institution of continual sacrifice points ahead to an unending sacrifice (see Heb. 10:1-10).

verses.text: And its drink offering shall be a quarter of a hin for each lamb: pour out the strong drink offering to the Lord in the sanctuary.
verses.comment: The addition of a drink offering symbolizes the totality of the offering—body and blood, flesh and wine. Such imagery is further developed in later Christian understanding of sacrifice (see Luke 22:20).

verses.text: The other lamb you shall offer at twilight; as the grain offering of the morning, and as its drink offering, you shall offer it as an offering by fire, a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
verses.comment: Repeating the offering at evening underscores the God-ordained regularity and solemn rhythm of worship (see Dan. 6:10 for Daniel’s prayer).

verses.text: On the Sabbath day, two male lambs a year old without blemish, and two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour as a grain offering, mixed with oil, and its drink offering:
verses.comment: The Sabbath offering doubles the daily sacrifice, showing the special sanctity of the Sabbath and a fuller rest in God (cf. Heb. 4:9).

verses.text: This is the burnt offering for every Sabbath, in addition to the continual burnt offering and its drink offering.
verses.comment: The Sabbath sacrifices are not a replacement but an addition to the continual burnt offering, showing the accumulation and perfection of worship.

verses.text: At the beginning of your months, you shall offer a burnt offering to the Lord: two bulls of the herd, one ram, seven male lambs a year old without blemish;
verses.comment: Monthly (new moon) offerings suggest God’s lordship over times and seasons, and a pattern of continual renewal. The number and quality of sacrifices again point to completion and perfection.

verses.text: three-tenths of an ephah of fine flour as a grain offering, mixed with oil, for each bull; two-tenths for the one ram;
verses.comment: Precise instructions for grain offerings reflect the principle that worship is not arbitrary but follows divinely established order.

verses.text: and a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil as a grain offering for each lamb, as a burnt offering, a pleasing aroma, a food offering by fire to the Lord.
verses.comment: The recurring phrase 'pleasing aroma' reinforces the intimate communion between God and His people through worship.

verses.text: Their drink offerings shall be half a hin of wine for a bull, a third of a hin for the ram, and a quarter of a hin for each lamb; this is the monthly burnt offering throughout the months of the year.
verses.comment: Wine as part of the sacrifice prefigures its ultimate use in the New Covenant, as instituted by Christ at the Last Supper (see Matt. 26:27-28).

verses.text: Also, one male goat for a sin offering to the Lord shall be offered, besides the continual burnt offering and its drink offering.
verses.comment: A sin offering among burnt offerings highlights ongoing human need for atonement, pointing toward a greater, perfect atonement to come.

verses.text: In the first month, on the fourteenth day of the month, is the Lord’s Passover.
verses.comment: Passover commemorates Israel’s deliverance, which is fulfilled in Christ, our Passover Lamb, sacrificed for us (1 Cor. 5:7).

verses.text: And on the fifteenth day of this month is a festival; for seven days unleavened bread shall be eaten.
verses.comment: Unleavened bread signifies purity and the removal of sin (Matt. 16:6, 12; 1 Cor. 5:8), thus it works as both literal and spiritual teaching.

verses.text: On the first day there shall be a holy convocation; you shall do no regular work.
verses.comment: A day set apart for worship highlights the sanctity of gathering and abstaining from ordinary labor before God. See Heb. 10:24-25.

verses.text: You shall offer a burnt offering, an offering by fire, a pleasing aroma to the Lord: two young bulls, one ram, and seven male lambs a year old; they must be without blemish.
verses.comment: Again, the requirement of unblemished animals points to the purity of the ultimate sacrifice in Christ.

verses.text: Their grain offering shall be of fine flour mixed with oil; three-tenths of an ephah for each bull, and two-tenths for the ram.
verses.comment: The grain offering as a part of every burnt offering underlines the unification of praise, provision, and worship.

verses.text: A tenth for each of the seven lambs;
verses.comment: The precision in offerings reflects God's requirement for attention and intentionality in worship.

verses.text: also one male goat as a sin offering, to make atonement for you.
verses.comment: Atonement is a central theme—here, the Old Testament shadow points to full forgiveness granted in Christ (Heb. 9:11-14).

verses.text: You shall offer these in addition to the burnt offering of the morning, which is for a continual burnt offering.
verses.comment: Festival offerings are added to, not substituted for, daily worship, showing the importance of regular, unbroken liturgical prayer.

verses.text: Thus you shall prepare for each of the seven days, as the food of an offering by fire, a pleasing aroma to the Lord; it shall be offered besides the continual burnt offering and its drink offering.
verses.comment: The repetition each day for seven days signifies spiritual perfection and fullness.

verses.text: On the seventh day you shall have a holy convocation; you shall do no regular work.
verses.comment: Festival cycles open and close with rest and assembly for worship, affirming the communal nature of faith.

verses.text: On the day of the firstfruits, when you offer a new grain offering to the Lord at your Feast of Weeks, you shall have a holy convocation; you shall do no regular work.
verses.comment: The Feast of Weeks (Pentecost) points forward to the outpouring of the Spirit and the birth of the Church in Acts 2.

verses.text: You shall offer a burnt offering, a pleasing aroma to the Lord: two young bulls, one ram, seven male lambs a year old;
verses.comment: The specified offerings further express thanksgiving and consecration.

verses.text: with their grain offering of fine flour mixed with oil, three-tenths of an ephah for each bull, two-tenths for the ram,
verses.comment: Again, the grain and oil signify the fruitfulness of the Spirit accompanying sacrifice.

verses.text: a tenth for each of the seven lambs;
verses.comment: The numerical precision reveals God’s desire for intentionality in worship.

verses.text: and one male goat, to make atonement for you.
verses.comment: Atonement remains central—see Heb. 9:22, which teaches that 'without the shedding of blood there is no forgiveness of sins.'

verses.text: You must offer them with their drink offerings, in addition to the continual burnt offering and its grain offering—they must be without blemish.
verses.comment: The repeated injunction for animals 'without blemish' anticipates the perfect sacrifice of Christ. The phrase 'in addition to' emphasizes ongoing, structured worship, which the early Church maintained in practice and meaning.
